contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=May 2010}} [[Image:Rainstick 01.png|200px|thumb|right|Traditional style cactus rainstick]] {{Infobox instrument | name =Rainstick | image = Rainstick.ogg | image_capt =sound of a rainstick | classification =percussion instrument | hornbostel_sachs = 112.13+133.1 | hornbostel_sachs_desc =vessel rattle with friction | inventors =uncertain, some theories include: Peru, Aztecs, enslavened African slaves in North America | related =[[Hosho]][[Maracas]]Rainstick[[Vibraslap]] }} A '''rainstick''' is a long, hollow tube partially filled with small pebbles or beans that has small pins or thorns arranged [[helix|helically]] on its inside surface. When the stick is upended, the pebbles fall to the other end of the tube, making a sound reminiscent of rain falling. It is designated 112.1+133.1 in the [[Hornbostelâ€“Sachs]] classification system. The rainstick is believed to have been invented by the Aztecs and was played in the belief it could bring about rainstorms. Rainsticks are usually made from any of several species of [[cactus]]. The cacti, which are hollow, are dried in the sun. The spines are removed, then driven into the cactus like nails. Pebbles or other small objects are placed inside the rainstick, and the ends are sealed. A sound like falling water is made when the rainstick has its direction changed to a vertical position. Rainsticks may also be made with other common materials like paper towel rolls instead of cactus, and nails or toothpicks instead of thorns and are often sold to tourists visiting parts of Latin America, including the Southern United States. ==See also== *[[Hosho (instrument)|Hosho]] *[[Maracas]] *[[Vibraslap]] ==References== * Exploratorium Article [http://www.exploratorium.edu/frogs/rain_stick/index.html Make your own rainstick] * There is an article in a Peruvian journal, Quepo (Roque & Ramirez 2005.
